hedline.hl1: Mexican Police Are Accused of Torture

block.p: The police tortured and beat suspected leaders of an Indian rebellion last year, and judges accepted the confessions although they knew they were coerced, a human-rights group asserted today.

The report by the Human Rights Watch/Americas, based in New York, represented a direct challenge to President Ernesto Zedillo, who has promised to clean up Mexico's corrupt judicial system and state security forces.
The police tortured and beat suspected leaders of an Indian rebellion last year, and judges accepted the confessions although they knew they were coerced, a human-rights group asserted today.

The report by the Human Rights Watch/Americas, based in New York, represented a direct challenge to President Ernesto Zedillo, who has promised to clean up Mexico's corrupt judicial system and state security forces.

The rights group urged the Government to prosecute the agents involved in torturing suspected leaders of the Zapatista National Liberation Army, and to address the systemic problems that can lead to rights abuses.
The Government referred questions about the report to the Foreign Relations Ministry. A spokeswoman there said she would respond to the accusations on Friday, after the report is officially released.
In November, the ministry said a report by the rights group Amnesty International, which made similar accusations, "exaggerated" human rights abuses in Mexico.

Human Rights Watch/Americas based its report in part on findings of the Government's own National Human Rights Commission, which confirmed that the police tortured suspects during a crackdown last year.
